intro: Phyllodoce verticillata, commonly known as the mountain heath, is a low-growing evergreen shrub native to the northern hemisphere. It is characterized by its dense, mat-forming growth habit and small, leathery leaves that are often clustered at the ends of its stems. The plant produces clusters of tiny, bell-shaped flowers in shades of white, pink, or red, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. It thrives in acidic, well-drained soils and is often found in rocky or boggy habitats. Phyllodoce verticillata is an important species in heathland ecosystems, providing habitat and food for various insects and small animals.
